docs.lead_paragraph: The Iowa Supreme Court is expected to rule whether a state medical board overstepped its authority by requiring doctors to be in the room when a woman receives abortion-inducing medication rather than allowing it to be administered remotely via video conferencing.

docs.lead_paragraph: The subject poses profound questions about the beginning of life, the definition of family and the advances opening new reproductive possibilities.

headline.main: Industry’s Growth Leads to Leftover Embryos, and Painful Choices
headline.print_headline: Industry’s Growth Leads to Leftover Embryos, and Painful Choices

docs.abstract: Families, clinics and courts are faced with challenge of what to do with estimated million frozen embryos left over in wake of assisted reproduction boom that followed the first successful 'test tube' babies; researchers say decision of what to do with embryos is difficult one for families, as it raises questions about life's beginnings, idea of family and ethics of technology that has allowed for new reproductive possibilities.
docs.snippet: The subject poses profound questions about the beginning of life, the definition of family and the advances opening new reproductive possibilities.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that adds momentum to efforts to integrate immigrants, California is on the cusp of extending state-subsidized health care coverage to children from low-income families who are in the country illegally.

docs.lead_paragraph: A GOP-controlled Senate panel on Tuesday approved a $31 billion spending bill slashing the Environmental Protection Agency's budget by more than $500 million and seeking to block the agency on clean air and water regulations, global warming, and hydraulic fracturing to extract oil and gas from federal lands.

headline.main: Senate GOP Bill Combats Obama Environmental Agenda

docs.lead_paragraph: Years ago, Ms. Dolezal, who is accused of deceiving people about her race, apparently sued Howard University, charging that it had discriminated against her — in part for being white.

headline.main: Rachel Dolezal Leaves N.A.A.C.P. Post as Past Discrimination Suit Is Revealed
headline.print_headline: N.A.A.C.P. Chapter Leader Resigns Amid Claims She Lied About Ethnicity

docs.abstract: Rachel A Dolezal quits as NAACP chapter president in Spokane, Wash, amid claims that she lied about her ethnicity; has claimed for years that her background was partly black, but her parents say she has no black ancestry.
docs.snippet: Years ago, Ms. Dolezal, who is accused of deceiving people about her race, apparently sued Howard University, charging that it had discriminated against her — in part for being white.

headline.main: Women’s Bodies Safe from North Carolina Lawmakers, For Now

docs.abstract: A North Carolina law that required women seeking abortions to get ultrasounds won’t be resurrected, but similar laws exist in other states.
